column1: Fermentation is a metabolic process that converts sugar to acids
column3: or alcohol. It occurs in yeast and bacteria
column4: and also in oxygen-starved muscle cells
column5: as in the case of lactic acid fermentation. Fermentation is also used more broadly to refer to the bulk growth of microorganisms on a growth medium
column6: often with the goal of producing a specific chemical product. French microbiologist Louis Pasteur is often remembered for his insights into fermentation and its microbial causes. The science of fermentation is known as zymology.Fermentation takes place when the electron transport chain is unusable (often due to lack of a final electron receptor
column8: and becomes the cell's primary means of ATP (energy) production. It turns NADH and pyruvate produced in glycolysis into NAD+ and an organic molecule (which varies depending on the type of fermentation; see examples below). In the presence of O2
column9: NADH and pyruvate are used to generate ATP in respiration. This is called oxidative phosphorylation
column10: and it generates much more ATP than glycolysis alone. For that reason
column11: cells generally benefit from avoiding fermentation when oxygen is available
column12: the exception being obligate anaerobes which cannot tolerate oxygen.
